image.altText: Mojib Rahman stands on a rooftop looking out to the horizon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's energy regulator says electricity prices will rise by up to 24 per cent from July 1, for around 600,000 customers in South Australia, New South Wales and South-East Queensland. The increase is higher than the draft offer put forward by the regulator in March, which suggested increases of between 20 and 22 per cent. You can read more on this breaking story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electricity prices to rise for around 600,000 customers again in July

featuredLink.title: Electricity prices to rise by up to 24 per cent in New South Wales, South-East Queensland and South Australia

children.content: Australia's energy regulator says
electricity prices will rise by up to 24 per cent from July 1
, for around 600,000 customers in South Australia, New South Wales and South-East Queensland.
The increase is higher than the draft offer put forward by the regulator in March, which suggested increases of between 20 and 22 per cent.
You can read more on this breaking story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has officially entered the 2024 US presidential race. He's stepping into a crowded Republican primary contest which will test his national appeal as an outspoken cultural conservative and the GOP's willingness to move on from former president Donald Trump — who is also running for presidnet. The 44-year-old DeSantis revealed his decision in a Federal Election Commission filing before an online conversation with Twitter CEO Elon Musk, which is expected to take place around 8am AEST this morning. DeSantis is considered to be Trump's strongest Republican rival even as the governor faces questions about his readiness for the national stage.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ron DeSantis confirms he's running against Trump for US president

props.alt: Three men, one with white hair, sit next to each other at a table, wearing suits and ties

expected to take place around 8am AEST this morning
DeSantis is considered to be Trump's strongest Republican rival even as the governor faces questions about his readiness for the national stage.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: American rapper Fetty Wap has been sentenced to six years in prison for his role in a New York-based drug trafficking scheme. The artist, whose legal name is Willie Maxwell, apologised for his actions and told a court he was "exactly where I'm supposed to be" before the sentencing. The Trap Queen rapper pleaded guilty in August 2022 to a conspiracy drug charge that carried a mandatory minimum sentence of five years. Maxwell told US District Judge Joanna Seybert, "Me being selfish in my pride put me in this position today." His lawyers had suggested he turned to selling drugs because of financial hardship brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic. Maxwell was arrested in October 2021 on charges of participating in a conspiracy to smuggle large amounts of heroin, fentanyl and other drugs into the New York City area.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rapper Fetty Wap handed prison sentence over drug trafficking scheme

props.alt: Rapper Fetty Wap, wearing a bandana, looks at the camera on a Grammys red carpet

carried a mandatory minimum sentence of five years

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here is the full table of default market offers for residential and small business customers in NSW, south-east Queensland and South Australia. It's important to remember that these are only the default offers — you could be paying a lot less, or potentially more, if you have chosen a non-default offer with your retailer. These are the prices that you'll pay if you haven't actively chosen an electricity price plan. Small businesses in much of Sydney, the Central Coast and Hunter covered by Ausgrid are set to face the smallest increase of 14.7%, while South Australian small businesses are bracing for a 28.9% price jump. Victoria's energy regulator will separately announce the default market offer for that state this morning. The draft determination flagged bigger price rises than the Australian Energy Regulator.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The full table of electricity default market offers: SA businesses to see 28.9% rise

Small businesses in much of Sydney, the Central Coast and Hunter covered by Ausgrid are set to face the smallest increase of 14.7%, while South Australian small businesses are bracing for a 28.9% price jump.
Victoria's energy regulator will separately announce the default market offer for that state this morning.
The draft determination flagged bigger price rises than the Australian Energy Regulator.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian Energy Regulator chair Clare Savage says the electricity bill assistance announced in the federal budget will mean that most people eligible for those subsidies will not see their power bills rise this year. "It's 50-50 funded between the federal government and most state governments, they'll receive a $500 rebate on their bill," she explained. "The price rises we're talking about today are mostly less than that. " So, in most circumstances, those eligible customers won't experience a price increase this year. " The subsidies will start from July 1 and apply to people on Centrelink payments and those who receive family tax benefit, as well as small businesses. The ABC's Danielle Maguire did a great job of explaining who is eligible in this article.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Most customers receiving government electricity subsidy won't see a price rise

featuredLink.title: Find out if you're eligible for the government's $500 energy bill relief payment with this state-by-state breakdown

children.content: Australian Energy Regulator chair Clare Savage
says the electricity bill assistance announced in the federal budget will mean that most people eligible for those subsidies will not see their power bills rise this year.
"It's 50-50 funded between the federal government and most state governments, they'll receive a $500 rebate on their bill," she explained.
"The price rises we're talking about today are mostly less than that.
So, in most circumstances, those eligible customers won't experience a price increase this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While a price rise of up to 24.9% for residential customers is a lot, Australian Energy Regulator Clare Savage says it would have been a lot worse if not for federal government market intervention last year. "When we were looking at the price, what the price increases could have been last September, October, we're estimating between about 35 and 50% would have been the number I would have had to announce today, which obviously would have been very terrible," she told RN Breakfast. "What we're seeing is that the contract that retailers buy for the coming financial year have fallen quite a bit since the intervention in the coal and gas markets in October last year, so they are about 40% lower than where they were in October last year. "But they're still much higher than where they were at the start of 2022 which is why we're still seeing an increase."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electricity price rises about half what they would have been without market intervention

children.content: While a price rise of up to 24.9% for residential customers is a lot, Australian Energy Regulator Clare Savage says it would have been a lot worse if not for federal government market intervention last year.

"When we were looking at the price, what the price increases could have been last September, October, we're estimating between about 35 and 50% would have been the number I would have had to announce today, which obviously would have been very terrible," she told RN Breakfast.

"What we're seeing is that the contract that retailers buy for the coming financial year have fallen quite a bit since the intervention in the coal and gas markets in October last year, so they are about 40% lower than where they were in October last year.
"But they're still much higher than where they were at the start of 2022 which is why we're still seeing an increase."
